calibration_line_thickness=to_int(self._get_widget_value('calibration_line_thickness'))\n )\n \n return config\n \n def _save_config_file(self):\n \"\"\"Save configuration to JSON file\"\"\"\n filename = filedialog.asksaveasfilename(\n title=\"Save Configuration\",\n defaultextension=\".json\",\n filetypes=[(\"JSON files\", \"*.json\"), (\"All files\", \"*.*\")]\n )\n \n if not filename:\n return\n \n try:\n config = self._collect_config_from_ui()\n config_dict = {\n 'source': config.source,\n 'model_path': config.model_path,\n 'camera_width': config.camera_width,\n 'camera_height': config.camera_height,\n 'camera_fps': config.camera_fps,\n 'cell_width': config.cell_width,\n 'cell_height': config.cell_height,\n 'person_radius': config.person_radius,\n 'detect_every': config.detect_every,\n 'confidence_threshold': config.confidence_threshold,\n 'min_bbox_area': config.min_bbox_area,\n 'yolo_imgsz': config.yolo_imgsz,\n 'use_deepsort': config.use_deepsort,\n 'max_age': config.max_age,\n 'n_init': config.n_init,\n 'centroid_distance_threshold': config.centroid_distance_threshold,\n 'ema_alpha': config.ema_alpha,\n 'fps': config.fps,\n 'hysteresis_time': config.hysteresis_time,\n 'alert_clear_offset': config.alert_clear_offset,\n 'occupancy_warning_threshold': config.occupancy_warning_threshold,\n 'max_birdseye_pixels': config.max_birdseye_pixels,\n 'grid_line_thickness': config.grid_line_thickness,\n 'bbox_thickness': config.bbox_thickness,\n 'info_panel_height': config.info_panel_height,\n 'font_size_large': config.font_size_large,\n 'font_size_medium': config.font_size_medium,\n 'font_size_small': config.font_size_small,\n 'font_size_tiny': config.font_size_tiny,\n 'font_size_birdseye': config.font_size_birdseye,\n 'enable_screenshots': config.enable_screenshots,\n 'enable_grid_adjustment': config.enable_grid_adjustment,\n 'fps_counter_window': config.fps_counter_window,\n 'split_view_divisor': config.split_view_divisor,\n 'calibration_point_radius': config.calibration_point_radius,\n 'calibration_line_thickness': config.calibration_line_thickness\n }\n \n with open(filename, 'w') as f:\n json.dump(config_dict, f, indent=4)\n \n self.status_var.set(f\"Configuration saved to {filename}\")\n messagebox.showinfo(\"Success\", f\"Configuration saved successfully to:\\n{filename}\")\n \n except Exception as e:\n messagebox.showerror(\"Error\", f\"Failed to save configuration:\\n{str(e)}\")\n \n def _load_config_file(self):\n \"\"\"Load configuration from JSON file\"\"\"\n filename = filedialog.askopenfilename(\n title=\"Load Configuration\",\n filetypes=[(\"JSON files\", \"*.json\"), (\"All files\", \"*.*\")]\n )\n \n if not filename:\n return\n \n try:\n with open(filename, 'r') as f:\n config_dict = json.load(f)\n \n # Update config object\n for key, value in config_dict.items():\n if hasattr(self.config, key):\n setattr(self.config, key, value)\n \n # Update UI\n self._load_config_to_ui()\n \n self.status_var.set(f\"Configuration loaded from {filename}\")\n messagebox.showinfo(\"Success\", f\"Configuration loaded successfully from:\\n{filename}\")\n \n except Exception as e:\n messagebox.showerror(\"Error\", f\"Failed to load configuration:\\n{str(e)}\")\n \n def _reset_to_defaults(self):\n \"\"\"Reset configuration to defaults\"\"\"\n if messagebox.askyesno(\"Confirm Reset\", \"Reset all settings to default values?\"):\n self.config = MonitoringConfig()\n self._load_config_to_ui()\n self.status_var.set(\"Configuration reset to defaults\")\n \n def _run_monitor(self):\n \"\"\"Run the monitoring system\"\"\"\n try:\n # Collect configuration\n config = self._collect_config_from_ui()\n \n # Build command line arguments\n args = [\n sys.executable, \"main.py\",\n \"--source\", str(config.source),\n \"--model\", config.model_path,\n \"--cell-width\", str(config.cell_width),\n \"--cell-height\", str(config.cell_height),\n \"--person-radius\", str(config.person_radius),\n \"--detect-every\", str(config.detect_every),\n \"--conf\", str(config.confidence_threshold),\n \"--min-bbox-area\", str(config.min_bbox_area),\n \"--max-age\", str(config.max_age),\n \"--n-init\", str(config.n_init),\n \"--ema-alpha\", str(config.ema_alpha),\n \"--fps\", str(config.fps),\n \"--hysteresis\", str(config.hysteresis_time)\n ]\n \n if config.use_deepsort:\n args.append(\"--use-deepsort\")\n if not config.enable_screenshots:\n args.append(\"--disable-screenshots\")\n if not config.enable_grid_adjustment:\n args.append(\"--disable-grid-adjustment\")\n \n # Start process\n self.process = subprocess.Popen(\n args,\n stdout=subprocess.PIPE,\n stderr=subprocess.STDOUT,\n text=True,\n bufsize=1\n )\n \n # Update UI\n self.run_button.config(state=tk.DISABLED)\n self.stop_button.config(state=tk.NORMAL)\n self.status_var.set(\"Monitoring system running...\")\n \n # Start output monitoring thread\n self.output_thread = threading.Thread(target=self._monitor_process_output, daemon=True)\n self.output_thread.start()\n \n except Exception as e:\n messagebox.showerror(\"Error\", f\"Failed to start monitoring system:\\n{str(e)}\")\n \n def _monitor_process_output(self):\n \"\"\"Monitor process output in background thread\"\"\"\n try:\n if self.process:\n for line in self.process.stdout:\n print(line, end='')\n \n self.process.wait()\n \n # Update UI when process ends\n self.root.after(0, self._on_process_ended)\n \n except Exception as e:\n print(f\"Error monitoring process: {e}\")\n \n def _on_process_ended(self):\n \"\"\"Called when monitoring process ends\"\"\"\n self.run_button.config(state=tk.NORMAL)\n self.stop_button.config(state=tk.DISABLED)\n self.status_var.set(\"Monitoring system stopped\")\n self.process = None\n \n def _stop_monitor(self):\n \"\"\"Stop the monitoring system\"\"\"\n if self.process:\n try:\n self.process.terminate()\n self.process.wait(timeout=5)\n except:\n self.process.kill()\n \n self.process = None\n self.run_button.config(state=tk.NORMAL)\n self.stop_button.config(state=tk.DISABLED)\n self.status_var.set(\"Monitoring system stopped\")\n \n def run(self):\n \"\"\"Run the GUI application\"\"\"\n self.root.mainloop()\n\n\ndef main():\n \"\"\"Main entry point for GUI\"\"\"\n root = tk.Tk()\n app = ConfigurationGUI(root)\n app.run()\n\n\nif __name__ == \"__main__\":\n Let me stop it and create a README for how to use it:"}],"tool_calls":[{"id":"toolu_012v751AoU4Yc9Cg6gZLbWCN","type":"function","function":{"name":"kill_shell","arguments":"{"shell_id": "0f0e76"}"}}]},{"role":"tool","name":"kill_shell","tool_call_id":"toolu_012v751AoU4Yc9Cg6gZLbWCN","content":"Successfully terminated background process: 0f0e76"},{"role":"assistant","content":[{"type":"text","text":""}],"tool_calls":[{"id":"toolu_01AsY1jXW2AjQVEvHVVkFitQ","type":"function","function":{"name":"write","arguments":"{"file_path": "E:/Stampede-Management/GUI_README.md", "content": "# Configuration GUI - User Guide\n\n## Overview\n\nThe Crowd Monitoring System Configuration GUI provides a user-friendly interface to manage all system parameters and run the monitoring application.\n\n## Launching the GUI\n\nRun the following command from the project directory:\n\n```bash\npython config_gui.py\n```\n\n## GUI Features\n\n### 1. Tabbed Interface\n\nThe GUI is organized into 8 tabs, each focusing on a specific configuration category:\n\n#### **Video Source Tab**\n- **Video Source**: Set camera index (0, 1, 2) or browse for a video file\n- **Model Path**: Path to YOLO model file (browse to select)\n- **Camera Settings**: Configure resolution (width/height) and FPS\n\n#### **Grid & Spatial Tab**\n- **Cell Width/Height**: Define grid cell dimensions in meters\n- **Person Radius**: Set person radius for capacity calculations (in meters)\n\n#### **Detection Tab**\n- **Detect Every N Frames**: Performance optimization (higher = faster, less accurate)\n- **Confidence Threshold**: Adjust detection sensitivity (0.0 to 1.0)\n- **Min BBox Area**: Filter out small/false detections (in pixels)\n- **YOLO Image Size**: Model input size (higher = slower but more accurate)\n\n#### **Tracking Tab**\n- **Use DeepSort Tracker**: Toggle between DeepSort and Centroid tracker\n- **Max Age**: Frames to keep track without detection\n- **N Init**: Frames required to confirm new track\n- **Distance Threshold**: Max distance for matching (Centroid tracker)\n\n#### **Smoothing & Alerts Tab**\n- **EMA Alpha**: Exponential moving average smoothing factor\n- **Expected FPS**: For timing calculations\n- **Hysteresis Time**: Alert debounce time (seconds)\n- **Alert Clear Offset**: Threshold offset for clearing alerts\n- **Warning Threshold**: Occupancy percentage to trigger warning\n\n#### **Visualization Tab**\n- **Display Settings**: Bird's eye view size, line thickness, panel height\n- **Font Sizes**: Adjust text sizes for different UI elements\n\n#### **Interactive Tab**\n- **Enable Screenshots**: Allow 's' key to save screenshots\n- **Enable Grid Adjustment**: Allow 'g' key to toggle grid size\n- **FPS Counter Window**: Number of frames to average for FPS display\n- **Split View Divisor**: Size divisor for split view mode\n\n#### **Calibration Tab**\n- **Point Radius**: Size of calibration points\n- **Line Thickness**: Thickness of calibration lines\n\n### 2. Control Buttons (Bottom Bar)\n\n- **Load Config**: Load configuration from a JSON file\n- **Save Config**: Save current configuration to a JSON file\n- **Reset to Defaults**: Restore all settings to default values\n- **Run Monitor**: Start the monitoring system with current settings\n- **Stop Monitor**: Stop the running monitoring system\n\n### 3. Status Bar\n\nLocated at the bottom, displays current system status and messages.\n\n## Usage Workflow\n\n### Basic Usage\n\n1. **Launch the GUI**\n ```bash\n python config_gui.py\n ```\n\n2. **Configure Parameters**\n - Navigate through tabs\n - Adjust parameters as needed\n - All changes are reflected immediately in the UI\n\n3. **Run the System**\n - Click \"Run Monitor\" button\n - The monitoring system will start with your configured settings\n - View output in the console/terminal\n\n4. **Stop the System**\n - Click \"Stop Monitor\" button\n - Or press 'q' in the monitoring window\n\n### Save/Load Configurations\n\n#### Save Configuration\n1. Click \"Save Config\" button\n2. Choose a location and filename (e.g., `my_config.json`)\n3. Configuration is saved for future use\n\n#### Load Configuration\n1. Click \"Load Config\" button\n2. Select a previously saved JSON file\n3. All settings are updated in the GUI\n\n### Configuration Profiles\n\nYou can maintain multiple configuration profiles for different scenarios:\n\n- **Indoor monitoring**: Higher confidence, smaller grid cells\n- **Outdoor monitoring**: Lower confidence, larger grid cells\n- **High accuracy**: Lower detect_every, higher YOLO image size\n- **Performance mode**: Higher detect_every, lower YOLO image size\n\n## Tips and Best Practices\n\n### Video Source\n- Use `0` for default camera, `1` for second camera, etc.\n- For video files, use the Browse button to ensure correct path\n- Test with a video file first before using a live camera\n\n### Detection Settings\n- Start with default values and adjust incrementally\n- Lower confidence threshold if missing detections\n- Higher confidence threshold if too many false positives\n- Increase `detect_every` for better performance on slower systems\n\n### Grid Settings\n- Cell size depends on your monitoring area\n- Typical values: 1-3 meters per cell\n- Person radius should match expected crowd density\n - Dense crowds: 0.3-0.5 meters\n - Normal: 0.5-1.0 meters\n - Sparse: 1.0-2.0 meters\n\n### Performance Optimization\n1. Increase `detect_every` (e.g., 5-10 frames)\n2. Reduce `yolo_imgsz` (e.g., 416 or 320)\n3. Lower camera resolution\n4. Disable DeepSort if not needed\n\n### Troubleshooting\n\n**GUI won't start:**\n```bash\n# Ensure tkinter is installed\npython -m tkinter\n```\n\n**Monitoring system won't run:**\n- Check that `main.py` exists in the same directory\n- Verify YOLO model path is correct\n- Check video source is accessible\n\n**Performance issues:**\n- Reduce detection frequency\n- Lower YOLO image size\n- Decrease camera resolution\n\n## Keyboard Shortcuts (During Monitoring)\n\nWhen the monitoring system is running, these keys are available:\n\n- `1` - Raw Camera View\n- `2` - Grid Overlay View\n- `3` - Detection View\n- `4` - Monitoring View (default)\n- `5` - Split View\n- `s` - Save Screenshot (if enabled)\n- `g` - Toggle Grid Size (if enabled)\n- `r` - Reset Grid to Original Size\n- `f` - Toggle FPS Display\n- `q` - Quit Monitoring\n\n## Configuration File Format\n\nSaved configurations are stored in JSON format. Example:\n\n```json\n{\n \"source\": \"0\",\n \"model_path\": \"model/yolov8n.pt\",\n \"camera_width\": 1280,\n \"camera_height\": 720,\n \"cell_width\": 2.0,\n \"cell_height\": 2.0,\n \"confidence_threshold\": 0.35,\n ...\n}\n```\n\nYou can manually edit these files if needed.\n\n## Advanced Features\n\n### Custom Color Schemes\nEdit `config.py` directly to customize colors (BGR format for OpenCV).\n\n### Multiple Monitors\n- Save different configurations for different monitoring locations\n- Load appropriate config when switching locations\n\n### Integration\nThe GUI can be extended to:\n- Connect to external databases\n- Send alerts via email/SMS\n- Log events to files\n- Generate reports\n\n## Support\n\nFor issues or questions:\n- Check the main project documentation\n- Review `CONFIG_REFERENCE.md` for detailed parameter explanations\n- Examine log files (`crowd_monitor.log`)\n\n## Quick Start Example\n\n1. Launch GUI: `python config_gui.py`\n2. Set Video Source to `0` (default camera)\n3. Keep all other default settings\n4. Click \"Run Monitor\"\n5. Press `4` for full monitoring view\n6. Press `q` to quit when done\n\nEnjoy using the Crowd Monitoring System!\n"}"}}]},{"role":"tool","name":"write","tool_call_id":"toolu_01AsY1jXW2AjQVEvHVVkFitQ","content":"Successfully created file at E:/Stampede-Management/GUI_README.md

"E:/Stampede-Management/calibration.py", "limit": 100}"}}]},{"role":"tool","name":"read","tool_call_id":"toolu_01EANkBocRTc6dzDRHhpY1fS","content":" 1"""
 2Camera calibration module.
 3Handles perspective transformation setup and user interaction.
 4"""
 5
 6from typing import Optional, Tuple
 7
 8import cv2
 9import numpy as np
 10
 11from config import MonitoringConfig
 12from geometry import GeometryProcessor
 13from logger_config import get_logger
 14
 15logger = get_logger(__name__)
 16
 17
 18class CameraCalibrator:
 19 """Handles camera calibration for perspective transformation"""
 20
 21 def __init__(self, config: Optional[MonitoringConfig] = None):
 22 """Initialize camera calibrator
 23 
 24 Args:
 25 config: Optional monitoring configuration for visual settings
 26 """
 27 self.config = config if config is not None else MonitoringConfig()
 28 self.geometry_processor: Optional[GeometryProcessor] = None
 29 self.world_width = 0.0
 30 self.world_height = 0.0
 31
 32 def calibrate(self, frame: np.ndarray) -> bool:
 33 """
 34 Perform camera calibration with user interaction.
 35 
 36 Args:
 37 frame: Calibration frame
 38 
 39 Returns:
 40 True if successful, False otherwise
 41 """
 42 try:
 43 logger.info("Starting camera calibration...")
 44
 45 # Get calibration points from user
 46 pts_img = self._get_calibration_points(frame)
 47 if pts_img is None:
 48 return False
 49
 50 # Get real-world dimensions
 51 world_width, world_height = self._get_world_dimensions()
 52 if world_width is None or world_height is None:
 53 return False
 54
 55 # Calculate homography matrices
 56 pts_world = np.array([[0, 0], [world_width, 0], [world_width, world_height], [0, world_height]],
 57 dtype=np.float32)
 58
 59 H_matrix = cv2.getPerspectiveTransform(pts_img, pts_world)
 60 inv_H_matrix = cv2.getPerspectiveTransform(pts_world, pts_img)
 61
 62 self.geometry_processor = GeometryProcessor(H_matrix, inv_H_matrix)
 63 self.world_width = world_width
 64 self.world_height = world_height
 65
 66 logger.info(f"Calibration completed: {world_width}x{world_height}m")
 67 return True
 68
 69 except Exception as e:
 70 logger.error(f"Calibration failed: {e}")
 71 return False
 72
 73 def _get_calibration_points(self, frame: np.ndarray) -> Optional[np.ndarray]:
 74 """
 75 Get calibration points from user with GUI.
 76 
 77 Args:
 78 frame: Frame to display for calibration
 79 
 80 Returns:
 81 Array of 4 calibration points or None
 82 """
 83 clicked_points = []
 84
 85 def click_callback(event, x, y, flags, param):
 86 if event == cv2.EVENT_LBUTTONDOWN:
 87 clicked_points.append((x, y))
 88 logger.info(f"Clicked point {len(clicked_points)}: ({x}, {y})")
 89
 90 try:
 91 # Try GUI-based calibration
 92 window_name = "Calibration - Click 4 corners"
 93 cv2.namedWindow(window_name, cv2.WINDOW_AUTOSIZE)
 94 cv2.setMouseCallback(window_name, click_callback)
 95
 96 logger.info("Click 4 ground reference points in clockwise order")
 97 logger.info("Press 'c' to continue after 4 points, or 'ESC' to cancel")
 98
 99 while True:
100 display_frame = frame.copy()"},{"role":"assistant","content":[{"type":"text","text":""}],"tool_calls":[{"id":"toolu_01Sn5FMzo22TZWGP48rsLtpP","type":"function","function":{"name":"read","arguments":"{"file_path": "E:/Stampede-Management/calibration.py", "offset": 120, "limit": 50}"}}]},{"role":"tool","name":"read","tool_call_id":"toolu_01Sn5FMzo22TZWGP48rsLtpP","content":"120 # Add instructions
121 instructions = [
122 f"Points: {len(clicked_points)}/4",
123 "Click corners clockwise",
124 "'c' to continue, ESC to cancel"
125 ]
126
127 y_pos = 30
128 for instruction in instructions:
129 cv2.rectangle(display_frame, (10, y_pos - 25), (400, y_pos + 5), (0, 0, 0), -1)
130 cv2.putText(display_frame, instruction, (15, y_pos),
131 cv2.FONT_HERSHEY_SIMPLEX, self.config.font_size_medium, (0, 255, 0), 2)
132 y_pos += 35
133
134 cv2.imshow(window_name, display_frame)
135 key = cv2.waitKey(1) & 0xFF
136
137 if key == ord('c') and len(clicked_points) >= 4:
138 break
139 elif key == 27: # ESC key
140 logger.info("Calibration cancelled")
141 cv2.destroyWindow(window_name)
142 return None
143
144 cv2.destroyWindow(window_name)
145
146 if len(clicked_points) >= 4:
147 return np.array(clicked_points[:4], dtype=np.float32)
148
149 except Exception as e:
150 logger.warning(f"GUI calibration failed: {e}")
151
152 # Fallback to manual entry
153 return self._manual_calibration_entry(frame)
154
155 def _manual_calibration_entry(self, frame: np.ndarray) -> Optional[np.ndarray]:
156 """
157 Fallback manual calibration point entry.
158 
159 Args:
160 frame: Frame to save for reference
161

201 def _get_world_dimensions(self) -> Tuple[Optional[float], Optional[float]]:
202 """
203 Get real-world dimensions from user.
204 
205 Returns:
206 Tuple of (width, height) in meters or (None, None)
207 """
208 try:
209 print("\nEnter the real-world dimensions of the calibrated area:")
210
211 while True:
212 try:
213 width_str = input("Width (meters): ").strip()
214 width = float(width_str.replace(',', '.'))
215 if width > 0:
216 break
217 print("Width must be positive")
218 except (ValueError, KeyboardInterrupt):
219 logger.info("Dimension input cancelled")
220 return None, None
221
222 while True:
223 try:
224 height_str = input("Height (meters): ").strip()
225 height = float(height_str.replace(',', '.'))
226 if height > 0:
227 break
228 print("Height must be positive")
229 except (ValueError, KeyboardInterrupt):
230 logger.info("Dimension input cancelled")
231 return None, None
232
233 return width, height

520 def _create_calibration_tab(self):
521 """Create calibration settings tab"""
522 frame = ttk.Frame(self.notebook)
523 self.notebook.add(frame, text="Calibration")
524
525 canvas = tk.Canvas(frame)
526 scrollbar = ttk.Scrollbar(frame, orient="vertical", command=canvas.yview)
527 scrollable_frame = ttk.Frame(canvas)
528
529 scrollable_frame.bind("<Configure>", lambda e: canvas.configure(scrollregion=canvas.bbox("all")))
530 canvas.create_window((0, 0), window=scrollable_frame, anchor="nw")
531 canvas.configure(yscrollcommand=scrollbar.set)
532
533 row = 0
534 ttk.Label(scrollable_frame, text="Calibration Display Settings", font=("", 10, "bold")).grid(row=row, column=0,
535 columnspan=3,
536 sticky=tk.W,
537 pady=(10, 5))
538
539 row += 1
540 ttk.Label(scrollable_frame, text="Point Radius:").grid(row=row, column=0, sticky=tk.W, padx=10, pady=5)
541 self.config_widgets['calibration_point_radius'] = ttk.Spinbox(scrollable_frame, from_=3, to=20, width=15)
542 self.config_widgets['calibration_point_radius'].grid(row=row, column=1, sticky=tk.W, pady=5)
543 ttk.Label(scrollable_frame, text="pixels").grid(row=row, column=2, sticky=tk.W, padx=10)
544
545 row += 1
546 ttk.Label(scrollable_frame, text="Line Thickness:").grid(row=row, column=0, sticky=tk.W, padx=10, pady=5)
547 self.config_widgets['calibration_line_thickness'] = ttk.Spinbox(scrollable_frame, from_=1, to=10, width=15)
548 self.config_widgets['calibration_line_thickness'].grid(row=row, column=1, sticky=tk.W, pady=5)
549 ttk.Label(scrollable_frame, text="pixels").grid(row=row, column=2, sticky=tk.W, padx=10)
550
551 canvas.pack(side="left", fill="both", expand=True)
552 scrollbar.pack(side="right", fill="y")

554 def _browse_video_source(self):
555 """Browse for video source file"""
556 filename = filedialog.askopenfilename(
557 title="Select Video File",
558 filetypes=[("Video files", "*.mp4 *.avi *.mov *.mkv"), ("All files", "*.*")]
559 )
560 if filename:
561 self.config_widgets['source'].delete(0, tk.END)
562 self.config_widgets['source'].insert(0, filename)

564 def _browse_model_path(self):

569 )
570 if filename:
571 self.config_widgets['model_path'].delete(0, tk.END)
572 self.config_widgets['model_path'].insert(0, filename)

896 args.append("--use-deepsort")
897 if not config.enable_screenshots:
898 args.append("--disable-screenshots")
899 if not config.enable_grid_adjustment:
900 args.append("--disable-grid-adjustment")
901
902 # Start process
903 self.process = subprocess.Popen(
904 args,
905 stdout=subprocess.PIPE,
906 stderr=subprocess.STDOUT,
907 text=True,
908 bufsize=1
909 )
910
911 # Update UI
912 self.run_button.config(state=tk.DISABLED)
913 self.stop_button.config(state=tk.NORMAL)
914 self.status_var.set("Monitoring system running...")
915
916 # Start output monitoring thread
917 self.output_thread = threading.Thread(target=self._monitor_process_output, daemon=True)
918 self.output_thread.start()
919
920 except Exception as e:
921 messagebox.showerror("Error", f"Failed to start monitoring system:\n{str(e)}")
922
923 def _monitor_process_output(self):
924 """Monitor process output in background thread"""
925 try:
926 if self.process:
927 for line in self.process.stdout:
928 print(line, end='')

152- Person radius should match expected crowd density

154 - Normal: 0.5-1.0 meters
155 - Sparse: 1.0-2.0 meters
156

158

"},{"role":"assistant","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Excellent! I've successfully added the calibration area configuration to the GUI. Here's what I've implemented:

## Summary of Changes

### 1. **Updated config.py** (config.py:123-126)
Added three new configuration parameters:
- `calibration_area_width`: float = 10.0 (meters)
- `calibration_area_height`: float = 10.0 (meters)
- `auto_calibration`: bool = False (use preset dimensions)

### 2. **Enhanced GUI** (config_gui.py)
Added a new section in the **Calibration Tab**:
- **Area Width** input field (1.0 to 100.0 meters)
- **Area Height** input field (1.0 to 100.0 meters)
- **"Use preset dimensions"** checkbox to enable automatic calibration
- Info text explaining the purpose
- Visual separator between area settings and display settings

### 3. **Updated calibration.py** (calibration.py:201-240)
Modified `_get_world_dimensions()` method to:
- Check if `auto_calibration` is enabled
- If enabled, use preset dimensions from config
- If disabled, prompt user for manual input (existing behavior)
- Log which method is being used

### 4. **Updated main.py** (main.py:73-103)
Added command-line arguments:
- `--calibration-width`: Calibration area width
- `--calibration-height`: Calibration area height
- `--auto-calibration`: Flag to use preset dimensions
- Passed these parameters to MonitoringConfig

### 5. **Updated GUI_README.md**
Added comprehensive documentation:
- Description of new calibration fields
- Usage instructions
- Benefits explanation
- Example scenarios for different area sizes

## How It Works

### User Experience:
1. User opens the GUI (`python config_gui.py`)
2. Goes to the **Calibration** tab
3. Sets area dimensions (e.g., Width: 10m, Height: 10m)
4. Checks "Use preset dimensions"
5. Clicks "Run Monitor"
6. System uses these dimensions automatically - **no manual input required!**

### Benefits:
- **Convenience**: No need to type dimensions every time
- **Consistency**: Same calibration across multiple runs
- **Configuration Management**: Save/load different area configurations
- **Flexibility**: Can still manually input if unchecked

The calibration area is now fully integrated into the UI, making it much easier for users to manage and configure their monitoring setup!"}]}]},"68665336-36da-41a3-b349-337644cd07ac":{"id":"68665336-36da-41a3-b349-337644cd07ac","name":"Investigating DeepShort Issue in Config_GUI (Lines 2831)","timestamp":1765734857124,"messages":[{"role":"user","content":[{"type":"text","text":"@Run: config_gui (28-31) check why deepshort not wokring"}],"context":[{"source_type":"run","console_name":"Run: config_gui","content":"configurationType: Python

**Welcome!** This guide explains the Crowd Monitoring System in simple terms, perfect for someone with basic Python
knowledge.

---

## Table of Contents

1. [What Does This System Do?](#what-does-this-system-do)
2. [How Does It Work? (The Big Picture)](#how-does-it-work-the-big-picture)
3. [Understanding Each File](#understanding-each-file)
4. [Step-by-Step: What Happens When You Run It](#step-by-step-what-happens-when-you-run-it)
5. [Key Concepts Explained](#key-concepts-explained)
6. [Interactive Controls](#interactive-controls)
7. [Common Questions](#common-questions)

---

## What Does This System Do?

Imagine you're managing a large outdoor event, festival, or public space. You need to:

- **Count how many people** are in different areas
- **Detect overcrowding** before it becomes dangerous
- **Get alerts** when too many people gather in one spot
- **Monitor everything in real-time** using cameras

This is exactly what the Crowd Monitoring System does! It:

- Uses a camera to watch an area
- Automatically detects and tracks people
- Divides the area into a grid (like a checkerboard)
- Counts how many people are in each grid cell
- Alerts you when a cell gets too crowded
- Shows everything on your screen with helpful visualizations

---

## How Does It Work? (The Big Picture)

Think of it like a **4-step process** that repeats continuously:

```
1. CAPTURE 
 Camera captures video frames (pictures)
 
2. DETECT 
 AI finds all people in the frame
 
3. TRACK 
 System follows each person across frames
 
4. MONITOR 
 Calculate occupancy and show alerts
```

This cycle repeats **15-30 times per second**, giving you real-time monitoring!

---

## Understanding Each File

Let's go through each Python file and understand what it does:

### 1. **main.py** - The Starting Point 

**What it does:** This is like the "power button" of the system. When you run this file, everything starts.

**Simple explanation:**

- Reads your settings (which camera to use, grid size, etc.)
- Starts all the other components
- Keeps everything running until you press 'q' to quit

**Key parts:**

```python
def main():
 # 1. Get settings from user
 config = parse_arguments()

 # 2. Create the monitoring system
 monitor = CrowdMonitor(config)

 # 3. Start monitoring
 monitor.initialize()
```

Think of it like starting a car: you turn the key, the engine starts, and all systems come online.

---

### 2. **detector.py** - The People Finder 

**What it does:** Finds people in camera images using AI.

**Simple explanation:**

- Uses a special AI model called "YOLO" (You Only Look Once)
- YOLO is trained to recognize people in images
- When given a picture, it draws boxes around every person it sees
- Returns the location of each box (like: "Person at position X, Y")

**How it works:**

1. Load the YOLO model (a file called `yolov8n.pt`)
2. Feed it a camera frame
3. Get back a list of boxes: `[x1, y1, x2, y2, confidence]`
 - `x1, y1` = top-left corner of the box
 - `x2, y2` = bottom-right corner of the box
 - `confidence` = how sure the AI is (0-100%)

**Analogy:** Think of it like a "Where's Waldo?" expert who can instantly spot all the people in a crowded picture!

---

### 3. **calibration.py** - Teaching the Camera About Space 

**What it does:** Helps the system understand real-world distances from the camera view.

**Why is this needed?**
Imagine looking at a photo of a room. You can see the floor, but you don't know:

- Is that floor 5 meters wide or 20 meters wide?
- Is someone standing 3 meters or 10 meters from the camera?

Calibration solves this by asking you to mark 4 corners of a rectangular area and tell it the real size.

**The process:**

1. System shows you the first camera frame
2. You click 4 corners of a known area (like a 10m x 10m square)
3. You type the real dimensions: "Width: 10, Height: 10"
4. System creates a "transformation" that converts pixels meters

**Analogy:** It's like giving someone a map scale: "1 inch on this map = 100 feet in real life"

**Visual example:**

```
Camera View Real World
 
 * * 10 meters
 
 * * 
 10 meters
(pixels) (actual distance)
```

---

### 4. **trackers.py** - Following People Over Time 

**What it does:** Keeps track of the same person across multiple frames.

**Why is this needed?**
The detector finds people in each frame, but doesn't know if the person in Frame 1 is the same person in Frame 2. The
tracker solves this by giving each person a unique ID and following them.

**Two tracking methods:**

#### A. **Simple Centroid Tracker** (Default)

- Finds the center point of each person
- In the next frame, matches people based on who's closest to where they were before
- Simple and fast!

**Example:**

```
Frame 1: Frame 2:
Person #1 at X Person at X + 2 Still Person #1 (moved slightly)
Person #2 at Y Person at Y + 1 Still Person #2 (moved slightly)
```

#### B. **DeepSort Tracker** (Advanced - Optional)

- Uses AI to remember what each person looks like (their appearance)
- More accurate but requires extra installation
- Better for crowded scenes where people overlap

**Analogy:** Like a security guard who remembers faces and can say "That's Person #17, they entered 5 minutes ago"

---

### 5. **geometry.py** - The Math Helper 

**What it does:** Converts between camera pixels and real-world meters.

**Simple explanation:**
Remember the calibration? This file uses that information to perform conversions:

- Camera says person is at pixel (640, 480) Convert to real position (5.2m, 3.8m)
- Need to draw a line at 10 meters Convert to pixel position to draw on screen

**Key functions:**

```python
# Convert real-world coordinates to screen pixels
world_to_image_point(5.0, 3.0) # 5m right, 3m down pixel (640, 480)

# Convert person's bounding box to real-world polygon
project_bbox_to_world(bbox) # box on screen shape on ground
```

**Analogy:** Like a GPS that converts latitude/longitude to distances, or vice versa.

---

### 6. **occupancy.py** - The Crowd Counter 

**What it does:** Divides the monitored area into a grid and counts people in each cell.

**Simple explanation:**

1. Divides the ground into a grid (like a checkerboard)
2. Each cell has a maximum capacity (e.g., 4 people)
3. For each person detected, figures out which cell(s) they're in
4. Keeps a running count for each cell
5. Triggers alerts when a cell exceeds capacity

**The grid system:**

```
Real World (divided into cells):

 2.3 1.1 0.5 Cell occupancy
 (decimal because we use
 4.2 5.8 3.1 smoothing - explained below)

 1.0 2.5 1.8 

```

**Important concepts:**

- **Cell Capacity:** Based on personal space
 - If each person needs 2m (r where r=person radius)
 - And each cell is 10m (2m 5m)
 - Capacity = 10/2 = 5 people per cell

- **EMA Smoothing:** Instead of instant counts, we use a "smooth" average
 - Prevents flickering numbers
 - Formula: `new_count = 0.4 current + 0.6 old_count`
 - This makes changes gradual rather than jumpy

- **Hysteresis:** Don't alert immediately; wait a few seconds
 - Prevents false alarms from people just walking through
 - Only alert if overcrowded for 3+ seconds

**Analogy:** Like a parking lot with sections - each section has a capacity, and you get an alert when Section B is
full.

---

### 7. **monitor.py** - The Command Center 

**What it does:** This is the "brain" that coordinates everything.

**Simple explanation:**
This file brings together all the other components:

- Gets frames from the camera
- Asks the detector to find people
- Asks the tracker to follow them
- Updates the occupancy grid
- Creates visualizations
- Handles your keyboard inputs

**The main loop:**

```python
while True: # Run forever until user quits
 # 1. Get a frame from the camera
 frame = camera.read()

 # 2. Detect people (every 3rd frame to save processing)
 if frame_count % 3 == 0:
 detections = detector.detect_persons(frame)

 # 3. Update tracks
 tracks = tracker.update_tracks(detections)

 # 4. Update occupancy grid
 occupancy_grid.update(tracks)

 # 5. Draw everything on screen
 display_frame = create_visualization(frame, tracks)

 # 6. Show it to the user
 show_on_screen(display_frame)

 # 7. Check if user pressed a key
 if key == 'q':
 break # Exit the loop
```

**Display modes:**
The system has 5 viewing modes you can switch between:

1. **Raw Camera** - Just the camera feed
2. **Grid Overlay** - Camera + grid lines
3. **Detection View** - Camera + boxes around people
4. **Monitoring View** - Everything together (default)
5. **Split View** - All views at once in a 22 grid

**Analogy:** Like the control room at NASA - monitors everything, coordinates all systems, and responds to commands.

---

### 8. **visualizer.py** - The Artist 

**What it does:** Creates all the graphics you see on screen.

**Simple explanation:**
This file is responsible for drawing:

- Bounding boxes around people (green rectangles)
- Person IDs (labels like "ID: 17")
- Grid lines on the ground
- Occupancy numbers in each cell
- Color-coded alerts (green = OK, orange = warning, red = overcrowded)
- Information panels with statistics
- Bird's eye view (top-down perspective)

**Color coding:**

- **Green:** Normal occupancy (safe)
- **Orange:** High occupancy (>80% capacity, warning)
- **Red:** Overcapacity (danger zone!)

**Drawing functions:**

```python
# Draw a box around a person
draw_track_annotation(view, track)

# Draw the grid on the camera view
draw_grid_overlay(view)

# Draw occupancy numbers in each cell
draw_cell_occupancy_overlay(view)

# Create a bird's eye view (top-down perspective)
create_birdseye_view(tracks)
```

**Analogy:** Like a graphic designer who takes raw data and makes it visually understandable.

---

### 9. **config.py** - The Settings File 

**What it does:** Stores all the settings and configuration options.

**Simple explanation:**
This file defines a "MonitoringConfig" class that holds all the knobs and dials:

- Which camera to use
- How big each grid cell should be
- How confident the AI needs to be to detect someone
- How long to wait before triggering an alert
- Whether screenshots are enabled
- And much more!

**Example settings:**

```python
config = MonitoringConfig(
 source="0", # Use camera 0 (default webcam)
 cell_width=2.0, # Each cell is 2 meters wide
 cell_height=2.0, # Each cell is 2 meters tall
 confidence_threshold=0.35, # AI must be 35%+ sure to detect
 fps=15.0, # Expect 15 frames per second
 enable_screenshots=True # Allow saving screenshots
)
```

**Analogy:** Like the settings menu in a video game - you can customize how everything behaves.

---

### 10. **logger_config.py** - The Record Keeper 

**What it does:** Saves messages and events to a log file.

**Simple explanation:**
Everything important that happens gets written down:

- "System started at 10:30 AM"
- "ALERT: Cell (2,3) is overcrowded"
- "Person #17 detected"
- "Screenshot saved: crowd_monitor_20231214.jpg"

These messages go to:

1. Your screen (so you can see them)
2. A file called `crowd_monitor.log` (so you can review later)

**Analogy:** Like a ship's log book or black box recorder - keeps a record of everything.

---

## Step-by-Step: What Happens When You Run It

Let's walk through exactly what happens from start to finish:

### **Phase 1: Startup (First 10-30 seconds)**

```
1. System starts (main.py runs)
 
2. Reads your settings
 
3. Loads the AI model (YOLOv8)
 - Downloads it if not present (about 6 MB)
 - This takes a few seconds
 
4. Opens the camera
 - Tries camera 0, then 1, then 2 if needed
 
5. Calibration begins
 - Shows you the camera view
 - Asks you to click 4 corners
 - Asks for real-world dimensions
 
6. Everything is ready!
 - Grid is created
 - Tracker is initialized
 - Monitoring begins
```

### **Phase 2: Continuous Monitoring (Main Loop)**

This repeats 15-30 times per second:

```
For each frame:

1. Capture frame from camera
 
2. Detect people (every 3rd frame)
 - YOLO AI finds all people
 - Returns bounding boxes
 
3. Track people
 - Match detections to existing tracks
 - Assign ID numbers
 
4. Update occupancy grid
 - Calculate which cells each person is in
 - Update counts with smoothing
 - Check for alerts
 
5. Create visualization
 - Draw boxes around people
 - Draw grid lines
 - Show occupancy numbers
 - Add information panels
 
6. Display on screen
 
7. Check for key presses
 - '1-5' to change view mode
 - 's' to save screenshot
 - 'q' to quit
 
8. Repeat!
```

### **Phase 3: Shutdown**

```
1. User presses 'q'
 
2. Loop exits
 
3. Camera is released
 
4. Windows are closed
 
5. System ends
```

---

## Key Concepts Explained

### 1. **What is YOLO (You Only Look Once)?**

YOLO is an AI model that can detect objects in images incredibly fast.

**How it works (simplified):**

- It's been trained on millions of images of people
- It learned what people look like from different angles, in different clothing, etc.
- When you give it a new image, it can instantly say: "Person here, person there!"
- It's called "You Only Look Once" because it processes the entire image in a single pass (very fast!)

**Why we use it:**

- It's fast enough for real-time video (30+ frames per second)
- It's accurate (90%+ detection rate)
- It's pre-trained (we don't need thousands of images)

### 2. **Perspective Transformation (Calibration Math)**

**The problem:**
A camera sees in perspective - things farther away look smaller.

```
Camera View:

 People far away look small
 
 People close look big

```

**The solution:**
Using the 4 corners you clicked, we create a "transformation matrix" that converts:

- Perspective view Bird's eye view (top-down)
- Pixels Meters

**The math (you don't need to understand this, but here it is):**

```python
H_matrix = cv2.getPerspectiveTransform(image_points, world_points)
```

This creates a 33 matrix that transforms coordinates. It's like magic!

### 3. **Exponential Moving Average (EMA) Smoothing**

**Without smoothing:**

```
Time: 0s 0.5s 1s 1.5s 2s
Count: 5 2 6 3 5 Jumpy!
```

**With EMA smoothing ( = 0.4):**

```
Time: 0s 0.5s 1s 1.5s 2s
Count: 5 4.2 4.9 4.3 4.5 Smooth!
```

**The formula:**

```
new_value = (alpha raw_count) + ((1 - alpha) old_value)
new_value = (0.4 raw_count) + (0.6 old_value)
```

This gives 40% weight to the new measurement and 60% to the history.

**Why this matters:**

- Prevents flickering numbers on screen
- Reduces false alarms from people briefly walking through
- Makes trends easier to spot

### 4. **Bounding Boxes**

A bounding box is a rectangle that contains an object.

**Format:** `[x1, y1, x2, y2]`

- `(x1, y1)` = top-left corner
- `(x2, y2)` = bottom-right corner

**Example:**

```
Image (800 600 pixels):

 
 Person's bounding box
 [200, 150, 350, 500]
 
 
 

```

### 5. **Track vs Detection**

**Detection:** A person found in a single frame

- "I see a person at position X in this frame"
- No history, no memory

**Track:** A person followed across multiple frames

- "This is Person #17, I've been following them for 2 minutes"
- Has history: where they've been, how long they've been here
- Has an ID that persists across frames

**Why tracks are better:**

- You can count unique people (not count the same person multiple times)
- You can track movement patterns
- You can calculate how long someone has been in a risky area

---

## Interactive Controls

When the system is running, you can press these keys:

| Key | Action | What It Does |
|-------|-----------------|----------------------------------------------------------|
| **1** | Raw Camera | Shows just the camera feed, no overlays |
| **2** | Grid Overlay | Shows camera + grid lines (helps you see cell divisions) |
| **3** | Detection View | Shows camera + boxes around detected people |
| **4** | Monitoring View | Shows everything (default) - this is the main view |
| **5** | Split View | Shows all 4 views at once in a 22 grid |
| **s** | Screenshot | Saves the current view to a file |
| **g** | Toggle Grid | Changes the grid size (more/fewer cells) |
| **r** | Reset Grid | Resets the grid to original size |
| **f** | Show FPS | Toggles FPS (frames per second) display |
| **q** | Quit | Exits the program |

**Pro tip:** Use Split View (press '5') to see everything at once while learning!

---

## Common Questions

### Q1: How accurate is the people detection?

**A:** The YOLO model is about 90-95% accurate in good conditions:

- **Good:** Well-lit areas, clear view, people standing
- **Okay:** Some occlusion (people partially hidden), varied poses
- **Poor:** Very dark, extreme angles, people lying down

### Q2: How many people can it track at once?

**A:** The system can handle:

- **Centroid Tracker:** 50-100 people (simple, fast)
- **DeepSort Tracker:** 30-50 people (more accurate but slower)

Performance depends on your computer's speed.

### Q3: What does "confidence threshold" mean?

**A:** It's how sure the AI needs to be before declaring "That's a person!"

- **Low threshold (0.2):** Detects more people, but more false positives
- **Medium threshold (0.35):** Balanced (recommended)
- **High threshold (0.6):** Only very obvious people, might miss some

**Example:**

```
AI confidence: 0.45 Detected! (above 0.35 threshold)
AI confidence: 0.30 Ignored (below 0.35 threshold)
```

### Q4: Why detect only every 3rd frame?

**A:** Running AI detection is slow (takes ~30-50ms). If we detect every frame:

- 30 frames/sec 50ms = Impossible!

By detecting every 3rd frame:

- 10 detections/sec 50ms = Only 500ms total
- The tracker fills in the gaps between detections
- You still get smooth tracking!

### Q5: What's the difference between a cell and a person?

**Cell:** A section of the grid (like a parking space)

- Fixed location
- Has a capacity (e.g., 4 people max)
- Can trigger alerts when overcrowded

**Person:** An individual detected by the system

- Moves around
- Can be in one or more cells
- Has a unique tracking ID

### Q6: Can I use a video file instead of a camera?

**A:** Yes! When running the system, use:

```bash
python main.py --source "path/to/video.mp4"
```

### Q7: What if calibration fails?

**A:** The system has a fallback:

1. It saves a screenshot: `calibration_frame.jpg`
2. You can open it in any image viewer
3. Find coordinates of the 4 corners (hover mouse to see pixel position)
4. Type them manually when prompted

### Q8: How much computer power do I need?

**Minimum:**

- CPU: Intel i5 or equivalent
- RAM: 4 GB
- No GPU needed (CPU-only works fine)

**Recommended:**

- CPU: Intel i7 or equivalent
- RAM: 8 GB
- GPU: NVIDIA GTX 1050 or better (10 faster!)

### Q9: Why use a grid instead of just counting total people?

**A:** Safety is about density, not just total count:

**Example:**

- 100 people spread evenly = Safe 
- 100 people all crowded in one corner = Dangerous! 

The grid helps identify **where** the problem is, not just that there is one.

### Q10: What does "world coordinates" mean?

**World coordinates:** Real-world positions in meters

- "Person is 5.2 meters right, 3.8 meters forward from the origin"

**Image coordinates:** Pixel positions on screen

- "Person is at pixel (640, 480) on the camera image"

The geometry processor converts between the two!

---

## Learning Path

If you want to understand the code better, study in this order:

1. **Start here:** `config.py` (simplest, just settings)
2. **Then:** `logger_config.py` (basic logging)
3. **Next:** `detector.py` (see how AI detection works)
4. **Then:** `geometry.py` (coordinate transformations)
5. **Next:** `trackers.py` (tracking logic)
6. **Then:** `calibration.py` (user interaction)
7. **Next:** `occupancy.py` (grid and counting)
8. **Then:** `visualizer.py` (drawing functions)
9. **Finally:** `monitor.py` (the complete system)
10. **Last:** `main.py` (entry point)

---

## Congratulations!

You now understand how the entire Crowd Monitoring System works! Key takeaways:

- **Camera** captures video
- **AI (YOLO)** finds people
- **Tracker** follows each person with an ID
- **Calibration** converts pixels to meters
- **Occupancy Grid** divides area and counts people per cell
- **Alerts** trigger when cells are overcrowded
- **Visualizer** shows everything on screen

The system runs a continuous loop, processing 15-30 frames per second, to provide real-time crowd monitoring and safety!

---

## Additional Resources

- **YOLOv8 Documentation:** https://docs.ultralytics.com/
- **OpenCV Tutorial:** https://opencv.org/
- **Computer Vision Basics:** https://www.pyimagesearch.com/

---

**Made with for beginners. Happy learning!** 
","ranges":[]},{"file_path":"trackers.py","code_text":""""
Tracking module for person tracking across frames.
Supports both simple centroid tracking and DeepSort.
"""

import math
from typing import Dict, List, Optional, Tuple

import numpy as np

from config import TrackData
from logger_config import get_logger

logger = get_logger(__name__)

# Import DeepSort with comprehensive error handling
try:
 from deep_sort_realtime.deepsort_tracker import DeepSort

 DEEPSORT_AVAILABLE = True
 logger.info("DeepSort successfully imported")
except ImportError as e:
 logger.warning(f"DeepSort not available: {e}")
 logger.info("Install with: pip install deep-sort-realtime")
 DEEPSORT_AVAILABLE = False
 DeepSort = None


class SimpleCentroidTracker:
 """Optimized centroid-based tracker with better performance"""

 def __init__(self, max_age: int = 30, distance_threshold: float = 80.0):
 """
 Initialize simple centroid tracker.
 
 Args:
 max_age: Maximum frames to keep track without detection
 distance_threshold: Maximum distance for track-detection matching
 """
 self.next_id = 1
 self.tracks: Dict[int, TrackData] = {}
 self.max_age = max_age
 self.distance_threshold = distance_threshold

 def update_tracks(self, detections: List[List[float]], frame: Optional[np.ndarray] = None) -> List[TrackData]:
 """
 Update tracks with new detections using optimized algorithm.
 
 Args:
 detections: List of detections as [x1, y1, x2, y2, confidence]
 frame: Optional frame for appearance-based tracking (unused in centroid)
 
 Returns:
 List of current TrackData objects
 """
 if not detections:
 self._age_tracks()
 return list(self.tracks.values())

 # Extract centroids efficiently
 centroids = [(det, (det[0] + det[2]) / 2, (det[1] + det[3]) / 2)
 for det in detections if len(det) >= 4]

 if not self.tracks:
 # Initialize tracks for first frame
 self._create_initial_tracks(centroids)
 else:
 # Match existing tracks to detections
 self._match_tracks_to_detections(centroids)

 self._remove_old_tracks()
 return list(self.tracks.values())

 def _create_initial_tracks(self, centroids: List[Tuple[List[float], float, float]]):
 """Create initial tracks for first frame"""
 for det, cx, cy in centroids:
 self.tracks[self.next_id] = TrackData(
 track_id=self.next_id,
 bbox=(int(det[0]), int(det[1]), int(det[2]), int(det[3])),
 world_position=(cx, cy),
 confidence=det[4] if len(det) > 4 else 1.0
 )
 self.next_id += 1

 def _match_tracks_to_detections(self, centroids: List[Tuple[List[float], float, float]]):
 """Match existing tracks to new detections using greedy algorithm"""
 used_detections = set()

 # Simple greedy matching - could be improved with Hungarian algorithm
 for track_id, track in list(self.tracks.items()):
 best_match = None
 best_distance = float('inf')

 for i, (det, cx, cy) in enumerate(centroids):
 if i in used_detections:
 continue

 # Calculate Euclidean distance
 distance = math.sqrt(
 (track.world_position[0] - cx) ** 2 +
 (track.world_position[1] - cy) ** 2
 )

 if distance < best_distance and distance < self.distance_threshold:
 best_distance = distance
 best_match = (i, det, cx, cy)

 if best_match:
 i, det, cx, cy = best_match
 used_detections.add(i)

 # Update track
 track.bbox = (int(det[0]), int(det[1]), int(det[2]), int(det[3]))
 track.world_position = (cx, cy)
 track.confidence = det[4] if len(det) > 4 else 1.0
 track.age = 0
 else:
 track.age += 1

 # Create new tracks for unmatched detections
 for i, (det, cx, cy) in enumerate(centroids):
 if i not in used_detections:
 self.tracks[self.next_id] = TrackData(
 track_id=self.next_id,
 bbox=(int(det[0]), int(det[1]), int(det[2]), int(det[3])),
 world_position=(cx, cy),
 confidence=det[4] if len(det) > 4 else 1.0
 )
 self.next_id += 1

 def _age_tracks(self):
 """Age all tracks when no detections are available"""
 for track in self.tracks.values():
 track.age += 1

 def _remove_old_tracks(self):
 """Remove tracks that are too old"""
 expired_tracks = [track_id for track_id, track in self.tracks.items()
 if track.age > self.max_age]
 for track_id in expired_tracks:
 del self.tracks[track_id]


class DeepSortTracker:
 """Wrapper for DeepSort tracker with error handling"""

 def __init__(self, max_age: int = 30, n_init: int = 1):
 """
 Initialize DeepSort tracker.
 
 Args:
 max_age: Maximum frames to keep track without detection
 n_init: Number of consecutive detections to confirm track
 """
 if not DEEPSORT_AVAILABLE:
 raise ImportError("DeepSort is not available")

 try:
 self.tracker = DeepSort(max_age=max_age, n_init=n_init)
 logger.info("DeepSort tracker initialized successfully")
 except Exception as e:
 logger.error(f"Failed to initialize DeepSort: {e}")
 raise

 def update_tracks(self, detections: List[List[float]], frame: Optional[np.ndarray] = None) -> List[TrackData]:
 """
 Update tracks using DeepSort.
 
 Args:
 detections: List of detections as [x1, y1, x2, y2, confidence]
 frame: Frame image for appearance feature extraction
 
 Returns:
 List of current TrackData objects
 """
 try:
 if not detections:
 tracks = self.tracker.update_tracks([], frame=frame)
 else:
 # Format detections for DeepSort (x, y, w, h, confidence)
 formatted_detections = []
 for det in detections:
 if len(det) >= 4:
 x1, y1, x2, y2 = det[:4]
 w, h = x2 - x1, y2 - y1
 conf = det[4] if len(det) > 4 else 0.9
 if w > 0 and h > 0:
 formatted_detections.append([float(x1), float(y1), float(w), float(h), float(conf)])

 tracks = self.tracker.update_tracks(formatted_detections, frame=frame)

 # Convert to TrackData format
 track_data_list = []
 for track in tracks:
 if hasattr(track, 'is_confirmed') and not track.is_confirmed():
 continue

 track_id = getattr(track, 'track_id', None)
 if track_id is None:
 continue

 # Get bounding box
 bbox = self._extract_bbox(track)
 if bbox is None:
 continue

 x1, y1, x2, y2 = bbox
 cx, cy = (x1 + x2) / 2, (y1 + y2) / 2

 track_data_list.append(TrackData(
 track_id=track_id,
 bbox=bbox,
 world_position=(cx, cy),
 confidence=1.0
 ))

 return track_data_list

 except Exception as e:
 logger.error(f"DeepSort tracking error: {e}")
 return []

 def _extract_bbox(self, track) -> Optional[Tuple[int, int, int, int]]:
 """Extract bounding box from track object"""
 try:
 if hasattr(track, 'to_tlbr'):
 tlbr = track.to_tlbr()
 return int(tlbr[0]), int(tlbr[1]), int(tlbr[2]), int(tlbr[3])
 elif hasattr(track, 'to_ltrb'):
 ltrb = track.to_ltrb()
 return int(ltrb[0]), int(ltrb[1]), int(ltrb[2]), int(ltrb[3])
 elif hasattr(track, 'to_ltwh'):
 ltwh = track.to_ltwh()
 x1, y1, w, h = ltwh
 return int(x1), int(y1), int(x1 + w), int(y1 + h)
 elif hasattr(track, 'bbox'):
 bbox = track.bbox
 if len(bbox) == 4:
 return tuple(map(int, bbox))
 except Exception as e:
 logger.warning(f"Failed to extract bbox: {e}")

 return None

665| def _set_widget_value(self, key: str, value: Any):
666| """Set widget value based on widget type"""
667| if key not in self.config_widgets:
668| return
669|
670| widget = self.config_widgets[key]
671|
672| if isinstance(widget, tk.BooleanVar):
673| widget.set(value)
674| elif isinstance(widget, (ttk.Entry, ttk.Spinbox, ttk.Combobox)):
675| widget.delete(0, tk.END)
676| widget.insert(0, str(value))
677| elif isinstance(widget, ttk.Scale):
678| widget.set(value)
679|
680| def _get_widget_value(self, key: str) -> Any:
681| """Get value from widget based on widget type"""
682| if key not in self.config_widgets:
683| return None
684|
685| widget = self.config_widgets[key]
686|
687| if isinstance(widget, tk.BooleanVar):
688| return widget.get()
689| elif isinstance(widget, (ttk.Entry, ttk.Spinbox, ttk.Combobox)):
690| return widget.get()
691| elif isinstance(widget, ttk.Scale):
692| return widget.get()

711|

719|

722| cell_height=to_float(self._get_widget_value('cell_height')),
723| person_radius=to_float(self._get_widget_value('person_radius')),
724|
725| # Detection

727| confidence_threshold=to_float(self._get_widget_value('confidence_threshold')),
728| min_bbox_area=to_int(self._get_widget_value('min_bbox_area')),
729| yolo_imgsz=to_int(self._get_widget_value('yolo_imgsz')),
730|
731| # Tracking

734| n_init=to_int(self._get_widget_value('n_init')),

736|

835| def _load_config_file(self):
836| """Load configuration from JSON file"""
837| filename = filedialog.askopenfilename(
838| title="Load Configuration",
839| filetypes=[("JSON files", "*.json"), ("All files", "*.*")]
840| )

843| return
844|
845| try:
846| with open(filename, 'r') as f:
847| config_dict = json.load(f)
848|
849| # Update config object

851| if hasattr(self.config, key):
852| setattr(self.config, key, value)
853|
854| # Update UI
855| self._load_config_to_ui()
856|
857| self.status_var.set(f"Configuration loaded from {filename}")
858| messagebox.showinfo("Success", f"Configuration loaded successfully from:\n{filename}")
859|
860| except Exception as e:

870| def _run_monitor(self):
871| """Run the monitoring system"""
872| try:
873| # Collect configuration
874| config = self._collect_config_from_ui()
875|
876| # Build command line arguments
877| args = [
878| sys.executable, "main.py",
879| "--source", str(config.source),
880| "--model", config.model_path,
881| "--cell-width", str(config.cell_width),
882| "--cell-height", str(config.cell_height),
883| "--person-radius", str(config.person_radius),
884| "--detect-every", str(config.detect_every),
885| "--conf", str(config.confidence_threshold),
886| "--min-bbox-area", str(config.min_bbox_area),
887| "--max-age", str(config.max_age),
888| "--n-init", str(config.n_init),
889| "--ema-alpha", str(config.ema_alpha),
890| "--fps", str(config.fps),
891| "--hysteresis", str(config.hysteresis_time)
892| ]
893|
894| if config.use_deepsort:
895| args.append("--use-deepsort")
896| if not config.enable_screenshots:
897| args.append("--disable-screenshots")
898| if not config.enable_grid_adjustment:
899| args.append("--disable-grid-adjustment")
900|
901| # Add calibration parameters
902| args.extend([
903| "--calibration-width", str(config.calibration_area_width),
904| "--calibration-height", str(config.calibration_area_height)
905| ])
906| if config.auto_calibration:
907| args.append("--auto-calibration")
908|
909| # Start process
910| self.process = subprocess.Popen(
911| args,
912| stdout=subprocess.PIPE,
913| stderr=subprocess.STDOUT,
914| text=True,
915| bufsize=1
916| )
917|
918| # Update UI
919| self.run_button.config(state=tk.DISABLED)
920| self.stop_button.config(state=tk.NORMAL)
921| self.status_var.set("Monitoring system running...")
922|
923| # Start output monitoring thread
924| self.output_thread = threading.Thread(target=self._monitor_process_output, daemon=True)
925| self.output_thread.start()
926|
927| except Exception as e:
928| messagebox.showerror("Error", f"Failed to start monitoring system:\n{str(e)}")
929|
930| def _monitor_process_output(self):
931| """Monitor process output in background thread"""
932| try:
933| if self.process:
934| for line in self.process.stdout:
935| print(line, end='')
936|
937| self.process.wait()
938|
939| # Update UI when process ends
940| self.root.after(0, self._on_process_ended)
941|
942| except Exception as e:
943| print(f"Error monitoring process: {e}")
944|
945| def _on_process_ended(self):
946| """Called when monitoring process ends"""
947| self.run_button.config(state=tk.NORMAL)
948| self.stop_button.config(state=tk.DISABLED)
949| self.status_var.set("Monitoring system stopped")
950| self.process = None
951|
952| def _stop_monitor(self):
953| """Stop the monitoring system"""
954| if self.process:
955| try:
956| self.process.terminate()
957| self.process.wait(timeout=5)
958| except:
959| self.process.kill()
960|
961| self.process = None
962| self.run_button.config(state=tk.NORMAL)
963| self.stop_button.config(state=tk.DISABLED)
964| self.status_var.set("Monitoring system stopped")
965|
966| def run(self):
967| """Run the GUI application"""
968| self.root.mainloop()
969|
970|
971|def main():
972| """Main entry point for GUI"""

980|"},{"role":"tool","name":"read","tool_call_id":"toolu_01EvqZ2o138wufeAPDbe6VbZ","content":" 1|"""
 2|Tracking module for person tracking across frames.
 3|Supports both simple centroid tracking and DeepSort.
 4|"""
 5|
 6|import math
 7|from typing import Dict, List, Optional, Tuple
 8|
 9|import numpy as np
 10|
 11|from config import TrackData
 12|from logger_config import get_logger
 13|
 14|logger = get_logger(__name__)
 15|
 16|# Import DeepSort with comprehensive error handling
 17|try:
 18| from deep_sort_realtime.deepsort_tracker import DeepSort
 19|
 20| DEEPSORT_AVAILABLE = True
 21| logger.info("DeepSort successfully imported")
 22|except ImportError as e:
 23| logger.warning(f"DeepSort not available: {e}")
 24| logger.info("Install with: pip install deep-sort-realtime")
 25| DEEPSORT_AVAILABLE = False
 26| DeepSort = None
 27|
 28|
 29|class SimpleCentroidTracker:
 30| """Optimized centroid-based tracker with better performance"""
 31|
 32| def __init__(self, max_age: int = 30, distance_threshold: float = 80.0):
 33| """
 34| Initialize simple centroid tracker.
 35| 
 36| Args:
 37| max_age: Maximum frames to keep track without detection
 38| distance_threshold: Maximum distance for track-detection matching
 39| """
 40| self.next_id = 1
 41| self.tracks: Dict[int, TrackData] = {}
 42| self.max_age = max_age
 43| self.distance_threshold = distance_threshold
 44|
 45| def update_tracks(self, detections: List[List[float]], frame: Optional[np.ndarray] = None) -> List[TrackData]:
 46| """
 47| Update tracks with new detections using optimized algorithm.
 48| 
 49| Args:
 50| detections: List of detections as [x1, y1, x2, y2, confidence]
 51| frame: Optional frame for appearance-based tracking (unused in centroid)
 52| 
 53| Returns:
 54| List of current TrackData objects
 55| """
 56| if not detections:
 57| self._age_tracks()
 58| return list(self.tracks.values())
 59|
 60| # Extract centroids efficiently
 61| centroids = [(det, (det[0] + det[2]) / 2, (det[1] + det[3]) / 2)
 62| for det in detections if len(det) >= 4]
 63|
 64| if not self.tracks:
 65| # Initialize tracks for first frame
 66| self._create_initial_tracks(centroids)
 67| else:
 68| # Match existing tracks to detections
 69| self._match_tracks_to_detections(centroids)
 70|
 71| self._remove_old_tracks()
 72| return list(self.tracks.values())
 73|
 74| def _create_initial_tracks(self, centroids: List[Tuple[List[float], float, float]]):
 75| """Create initial tracks for first frame"""
 76| for det, cx, cy in centroids:
 77| self.tracks[self.next_id] = TrackData(
 78| track_id=self.next_id,
 79| bbox=(int(det[0]), int(det[1]), int(det[2]), int(det[3])),
 80| world_position=(cx, cy),
 81| confidence=det[4] if len(det) > 4 else 1.0
 82| )
 83| self.next_id += 1
 84|
 85| def _match_tracks_to_detections(self, centroids: List[Tuple[List[float], float, float]]):
 86| """Match existing tracks to new detections using greedy algorithm"""
 87| used_detections = set()
 88|
 89| # Simple greedy matching - could be improved with Hungarian algorithm
 90| for track_id, track in list(self.tracks.items()):
 91| best_match = None
 92| best_distance = float('inf')
 93|
 94| for i, (det, cx, cy) in enumerate(centroids):
 95| if i in used_detections:
 96| continue
 97|
 98| # Calculate Euclidean distance
 99| distance = math.sqrt(
100| (track.world_position[0] - cx) ** 2 +
101| (track.world_position[1] - cy) ** 2
102| )
103|
104| if distance < best_distance and distance < self.distance_threshold:
105| best_distance = distance
106| best_match = (i, det, cx, cy)
107|
108| if best_match:
109| i, det, cx, cy = best_match
110| used_detections.add(i)
111|
112| # Update track
113| track.bbox = (int(det[0]), int(det[1]), int(det[2]), int(det[3]))
114| track.world_position = (cx, cy)
115| track.confidence = det[4] if len(det) > 4 else 1.0
116| track.age = 0
117| else:
118| track.age += 1
119|
120| # Create new tracks for unmatched detections
121| for i, (det, cx, cy) in enumerate(centroids):
122| if i not in used_detections:
123| self.tracks[self.next_id] = TrackData(
124| track_id=self.next_id,
125| bbox=(int(det[0]), int(det[1]), int(det[2]), int(det[3])),
126| world_position=(cx, cy),
127| confidence=det[4] if len(det) > 4 else 1.0
128| )
129| self.next_id += 1
130|
131| def _age_tracks(self):
132| """Age all tracks when no detections are available"""
133| for track in self.tracks.values():
134| track.age += 1
135|
136| def _remove_old_tracks(self):
137| """Remove tracks that are too old"""
138| expired_tracks = [track_id for track_id, track in self.tracks.items()
139| if track.age > self.max_age]
140| for track_id in expired_tracks:
141| del self.tracks[track_id]
142|
143|
144|class DeepSortTracker:
145| """Wrapper for DeepSort tracker with error handling"""
146|
147| def __init__(self, max_age: int = 30, n_init: int = 1):
148| """
149| Initialize DeepSort tracker.
150| 
151| Args:
152| max_age: Maximum frames to keep track without detection
153| n_init: Number of consecutive detections to confirm track
154| """
155| if not DEEPSORT_AVAILABLE:
156| raise ImportError("DeepSort is not available")
157|
158| try:
159| self.tracker = DeepSort(max_age=max_age, n_init=n_init)
160| logger.info("DeepSort tracker initialized successfully")
161| except Exception as e:
162| logger.error(f"Failed to initialize DeepSort: {e}")
163| raise
164|
165| def update_tracks(self, detections: List[List[float]], frame: Optional[np.ndarray] = None) -> List[TrackData]:
166| """
167| Update tracks using DeepSort.
168| 
169| Args:
170| detections: List of detections as [x1, y1, x2, y2, confidence]
171| frame: Frame image for appearance feature extraction
172| 
173| Returns:
174| List of current TrackData objects
175| """
176| try:
177| if not detections:
178| tracks = self.tracker.update_tracks([], frame=frame)
179| else:
180| # Format detections for DeepSort (x, y, w, h, confidence)
181| formatted_detections = []
182| for det in detections:
183| if len(det) >= 4:
184| x1, y1, x2, y2 = det[:4]
185| w, h = x2 - x1, y2 - y1
186| conf = det[4] if len(det) > 4 else 0.9
187| if w > 0 and h > 0:
188| formatted_detections.append([float(x1), float(y1), float(w), float(h), float(conf)])
189|
190| tracks = self.tracker.update_tracks(formatted_detections, frame=frame)
191|
192| # Convert to TrackData format
193| track_data_list = []
194| for track in tracks:
195| if hasattr(track, 'is_confirmed') and not track.is_confirmed():
196| continue
197|
198| track_id = getattr(track, 'track_id', None)
199| if track_id is None:
200| continue
201|
202| # Get bounding box
203| bbox = self._extract_bbox(track)
204| if bbox is None:
205| continue
206|
207| x1, y1, x2, y2 = bbox
208| cx, cy = (x1 + x2) / 2, (y1 + y2) / 2
209|
210| track_data_list.append(TrackData(
211| track_id=track_id,
212| bbox=bbox,
213| world_position=(cx, cy),
214| confidence=1.0
215| ))
216|
217| return track_data_list
218|
219| except Exception as e:
220| logger.error(f"DeepSort tracking error: {e}")
221| return []
222|
223| def _extract_bbox(self, track) -> Optional[Tuple[int, int, int, int]]:
224| """Extract bounding box from track object"""
225| try:
226| if hasattr(track, 'to_tlbr'):
227| tlbr = track.to_tlbr()
228| return int(tlbr[0]), int(tlbr[1]), int(tlbr[2]), int(tlbr[3])
229| elif hasattr(track, 'to_ltrb'):
230| ltrb = track.to_ltrb()
231| return int(ltrb[0]), int(ltrb[1]), int(ltrb[2]), int(ltrb[3])
232| elif hasattr(track, 'to_ltwh'):
233| ltwh = track.to_ltwh()
234| x1, y1, w, h = ltwh
235| return int(x1), int(y1), int(x1 + w), int(y1 + h)
236| elif hasattr(track, 'bbox'):
237| bbox = track.bbox
238| if len(bbox) == 4:
239| return tuple(map(int, bbox))
240| except Exception as e:
241| logger.warning(f"Failed to extract bbox: {e}")
242|
243| return None

 17|def parse_arguments() -> MonitoringConfig:
 18| """
 19| Parse command line arguments and create configuration.
 20| 
 21| Returns:
 22| Monitoring configuration object
 23| """
 24| parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(
 25| description="Enhanced Crowd Monitoring System with Interactive Features",
 26| formatter_class=argparse.ArgumentDefaultsHelpFormatter
 27| )
 28|
 29| # Video source and model
 30| parser.add_argument("--source", type=str, default="0",
 31| help="Video source (camera index or video file path)")
 32| parser.add_argument("--model", type=str, default="model/yolov8n.pt",
 33| help="YOLO model path")
 34|
 35| # Spatial parameters
 36| parser.add_argument("--cell-width", type=float, default=2.0,
 37| help="Grid cell width in meters")
 38| parser.add_argument("--cell-height", type=float, default=2.0,
 39| help="Grid cell height in meters")
 40| parser.add_argument("--person-radius", type=float, default=2,
 41| help="Person radius for capacity calculation (meters)")
 42|
 43| # Detection parameters
 44| parser.add_argument("--detect-every", type=int, default=3,
 45| help="Run detection every N frames")
 46| parser.add_argument("--conf", type=float, default=0.35,
 47| help="Detection confidence threshold")
 48| parser.add_argument("--min-bbox-area", type=int, default=1500,
 49| help="Minimum bounding box area")
 50|
 51| # Tracking parameters
 52| parser.add_argument("--use-deepsort", action="store_true",
 53| help="Use DeepSort tracker (requires installation)")
 54| parser.add_argument("--max-age", type=int, default=30,
 55| help="Maximum age for tracks")
 56| parser.add_argument("--n-init", type=int, default=1,
 57| help="Number of frames to confirm track")
 58|
 59| # Smoothing and alert settings
 60| parser.add_argument("--ema-alpha", type=float, default=0.4,
 61| help="EMA smoothing factor")
 62| parser.add_argument("--fps", type=float, default=15.0,
 63| help="Expected FPS for timing calculations")
 64| parser.add_argument("--hysteresis", type=float, default=3.0,
 65| help="Alert hysteresis time in seconds")
 66|
 67| # Interactive features
 68| parser.add_argument("--disable-screenshots", action="store_true",
 69| help="Disable screenshot functionality")
 70| parser.add_argument("--disable-grid-adjustment", action="store_true",
 71| help="Disable runtime grid adjustment")
 72|
 73| # Calibration area
 74| parser.add_argument("--calibration-width", type=float, default=10.0,
 75| help="Calibration area width in meters")
 76| parser.add_argument("--calibration-height", type=float, default=10.0,
 77| help="Calibration area height in meters")
 78| parser.add_argument("--auto-calibration", action="store_true",
 79| help="Use preset calibration dimensions (skip manual input)")
 80|
 81| args = parser.parse_args()
 82|
 83| # Create configuration object
 84| config = MonitoringConfig(
 85| source=args.source,
 86| model_path=args.model,
 87| cell_width=args.cell_width,
 88| cell_height=args.cell_height,
 89| person_radius=args.person_radius,
 90| detect_every=args.detect_every,
 91| confidence_threshold=args.conf,
 92| min_bbox_area=args.min_bbox_area,
 93| use_deepsort=args.use_deepsort,
 94| max_age=args.max_age,
 95| n_init=args.n_init,
 96| ema_alpha=args.ema_alpha,
 97| fps=args.fps,
 98| hysteresis_time=args.hysteresis,
 99| enable_screenshots=not args.disable_screenshots,
100| enable_grid_adjustment=not args.disable_grid_adjustment,
101| calibration_area_width=args.calibration_width,
102| calibration_area_height=args.calibration_height,
103| auto_calibration=args.auto_calibration
104| )
105|
106| return config
107|
108|
109|def main():
110| """Main entry point"""
111| try:
112| # Parse configuration
113| config = parse_arguments()
114|
115| logger.info("=== Enhanced Crowd Monitoring System ===")
116| logger.info(f"Video source: {config.source}")
117| logger.info(f"YOLO model: {config.model_path}")
118| logger.info(f"Grid cell size: {config.cell_width}x{config.cell_height}m")
119| logger.info(f"Person radius: {config.person_radius}m")
120| logger.info(f"Using tracker: {'DeepSort' if config.use_deepsort else 'Centroid'}")
121| logger.info(f"Interactive features: Screenshots={config.enable_screenshots}, "
122| f"Grid adjustment={config.enable_grid_adjustment}")
123|
124| # Initialize and run monitoring system
125| monitor = CrowdMonitor(config)
126| success = monitor.initialize()
127|
128| if success:
129| logger.info("Monitoring completed successfully")
130| else:
131| logger.error("Monitoring failed to initialize")
132| return 1
133|
134| except KeyboardInterrupt:
135| logger.info("System interrupted by user")
136| return 0
137| except Exception as e:
138| logger.error(f"System error: {e}")
139| return 1
140| finally:
141| # Cleanup
142| try:
143| cv2.destroyAllWindows()
144| except Exception:
145| pass
146|
147| return 0
148|
149|
150|if __name__ == "__main__":
151| sys.exit(main())

## Summary

### Problem
**DeepSort tracking was not working** in your Crowd Monitoring System. The error messages showed:
- `WARNING - DeepSort not available: No module named 'deep_sort_realtime'`
- System fell back to simple centroid tracker instead

### Root Cause
The `deep-sort-realtime` package was **not installed**. It was commented out in the `requirements.txt` file (line 17), so it wasn't installed during the initial setup.

### Solution Applied
1. **Installed deep-sort-realtime package** using: `pip install --only-binary :all: deep-sort-realtime`
2. **Updated requirements.txt** to uncomment the dependency
3. **Verified the installation** - DeepSort now imports and initializes successfully

### Results
- **DeepSort is now fully functional** and can be used in your application
- The tracker initializes with MobileNetV2 embedder for appearance-based tracking
- You can now use the `--use-deepsort` flag or enable it in the GUI

### How to Use
**From command line:**
```bash
python main.py --use-deepsort
```

**From GUI:**
Go to the "Tracking" tab and check the "Use DeepSort Tracker" checkbox

### Notes
- DeepSort provides better tracking accuracy using appearance features (MobileNetV2)
- It's more computationally intensive than the simple centroid tracker
- The installation downgraded opencv-python from 4.12.0.88 to 4.11.0.86 (this shouldn't affect functionality)
